turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Number 250, Lloyd Eldon Miller Jr. versus Frank J. Pate, Warden.
Mr. Lassers.

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, this is a capital case that comes to this Court on habeas corpus.
Relief was granted by the District Court of the Northern District of Illinois, Judge Perry, the state took an appeal and the Seventh Circuit reversed and this Court granted certiorari.
There are four principal errors that we contend occurred in this trial and I'm going to try cover the four.
The case is unique, Your Honors, and that the covenants on exonerating this petitioner of the crime was discovered even before the petitioner himself was arrested.

The -- the petitioner was convicted of murder and on Saturday afternoon, November 26th, 1955 in Canton, Illinois at 4:00 in the afternoon and a little eight year old girl was found under a mining car severely injured but still living.
She was rushed to a hospital where she dies at 5:47 P.M. that afternoon.
At 6:20, while the body was still on the operating table, the coroner arrived and he performed an examination.
Now, the coroner himself was a physician.

In the course of that examination, he took a vaginal smear and there had been a sex attack on this child and he took the smear and the vaginal smear was sealed in a vial with a surgical tape and this smear together with a mass of other evidence was immediately taken to Springfield which was few miles away and it was taken to the state crime laboratory there.

When it arrived there, the man in-charge, a man by the name of Forest literally, had found the vial and it was still sealed and it had on it Janice May, the name of the victim and the date of the crime November 26th, 1955 and the initials of the coroner.
He opened the vial and inside was a tissue which he examined.
And when he made a close examination, he found that there was a single strand of hair that was adhering to the tissue.
The petitioner Lloyd Eldon Miller was arrested the following day on November the 29th, at about six o'clock -- no about eight o'clock in the evening, on a Monday.
The crime took place on Saturday and he was arrested on Monday.

He was immediately taken to Springfield which was the same place for the state crime laboratory was located and he -- they took him up to the crime laboratory and they took blood sample and this and that and other things and among -- there are other examinations, they took a sample of his pubic hairs.
And immediately after that, on the night of the November the 29th, they had an extensive period of interrogation which lasted I believe until one in the morning.

He was taken back to his cell on the following night, the night of the 30th, there was another extensive period of examination and he signed a confession shortly after midnight on Wednesday evening which was the second night of the examination.
Now, he was tried in Carthage Illinois, in September of 1956 and which was about eight months -- ten months afterwards.

And in May, which was several months before the -- before the trial, the -- his then defense attorneys, we were not representing him at the time, filed a motion on the trial court asking, I believe, to make a physical examination of the evidence.

And the state came in and they resisted that, and the trial court denied the motion, and they preserved the error in the record and the Supreme Court of Illinois affirmed the denial of the right to make a physical examination of the evidence and the -- they affirmed the conviction.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Specifically what evidence?
What -- what evidence did he want physically to examine?

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: Well, there was --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: The vial?

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: The -- there was a physical evidence that was later introduced to the trial.
I don't think that they knew themselves exactly what physical evidence there was.
But there were various -- there was a -- that there was a pair of shorts which we can talk about later on.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, I just wondered whether the motion referred to anything specific or just generally asked permission to examine all physical evidence.

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: I believe that is correct.
I assume that's right.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Did the hair a part of evidence in the trial?

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: It was not Your Honor, no.
Now, the record -- what?

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Offered?

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: It was not offered, no, no.
Now, the petitioner --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Could I ask -- could I ask you another question?

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Was there any proof that he were at any stage in supplementary proceeding, or otherwise, that the pubic hair was actually found in the vagina?

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: The -- the record shows that the -- that the physician came and that we thought the vial was there and it have the initials of the coroner, it was still sealed, with the name of the child and the date of the crime, and that this was then sent to the crime laboratory, and that is the extent of the record.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: In other words, the hair was in the vial?

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: The hair was on -- was adhering to a tissue in the vial --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: In the vial?

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But the person who actually took the smear never testified that he found a hair in the vagina?

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: No, he did not.
He have --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And that's only an inference from the fact that the hair was in the vial?
That -- that you think it came from the vagina at the time.

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: Mr. Justice White, we think that the inference on that is just overwhelming.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes, but wholly aside of how you characterized it, that's what it rest on.

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: That is correct.
Now, the -- it is also a fact that this coroner did testify.
He was called as a witness by the prosecution and he did testify and he said that when he arrived there, the girl was dead and I believe he said that she was still on the operating table.
Now, the -- the counsel for the defendant at the time was permitted to physically to view the physical evidence on one occasion and he subsequently testified in subsequent proceedings.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, what does that mean?
Allowed physically to view -- what's that?

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: Well, he -- he went into the room and the evidence was put on a table before him and he with his co-counsel and they -- they looked.
I don't know whether they were allowed to touch or not.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, how does that different from what they sought on --

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: What they sought was permission to have a scientific examination made which would involve bringing in specialists in various kinds --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Now, did they see this after the motion was denied but before trial?

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: I believe that's correct, Your Honor.
Now, after they --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Did they see what before -- before trial but after -- after their --

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: They saw a pair of short, a jacket, and a rock, and --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: The vial?

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: I think they saw the vial, yes.
Now, it --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Was the hair observable?

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: I don't know -- I don't know whether the record shows whether it was or it was not.
It may have been.
Now --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Was it called to their attention that there was such a thing --

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: The record --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- in the vial?

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: The record does not show that it was ever called to their attention.
However, the petitioner testified that he was showing a hair and I will come --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: He was shown what?

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: -- to that in just a moment.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: He was shown what?

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: That he was shown a hair.

During the course of his interrogation and this was on the second night and it was shortly before he signed a confession, he testified that he was shown a hair, that he was taken into a microscope room which is what he called it, and that he was told that one of his hairs matched the hair from the little -- that was found in the little girl and he said that that -- they told him that he could look at the microscope through himself and then he said that he informed the people present them hairs don't match.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: That -- that what?

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: Them hairs don't match.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: That -- the petitioner's said that?

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: That is correct, Your Honor and he -- he so testified at the -- at the hearing on the motion to admit the confession.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well now, what did the -- the police concede that they had shown him a hair during the period that that is --

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: There was no denial of this.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: No denial?

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: The record on the prosecution side assigned on that issue.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But there's no concession that it was shown?

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: It's silent.
And I -- I think it's a fair to say that they have conceded, that they showed him the hair and that they told him that the hairs matched.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Now, when was it -- how long after this was -- that was determined that in fact this was not a hair from his body?

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: Eight years, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Eight years from --

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: Eight years, yes sir.
It was -- then, what happened was after the affirmance --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, when did the police first know that it was not a hair from his body?

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: At the very latest, on December the 7th of 1955 --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: That?

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: -- which was -- and we think it's a fair inference from the record that they knew it the very afternoon that the hair was delivered to the crime laboratory which was a day or two after the crime.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, in any event, at the time he was shown the hair and told that it was from his body, the police knew that in fact it was not from his body.

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: Well, the -- the -- we think that that is the inescapable inference from the record.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, what I'm trying to get to is, how do we know that police knew that it was not from his body at the time they told him it was?
What in the record shows that?

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: Only -- it's only the inference and based on this fact that the hair was already in the crime laboratory for over 24 hours at the time they made the false statement to him.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: It was there but I'm still uncertain how it is they knew it was not his.
When was it determined and by whom was it determined that it was not a hair --

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: It was --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- from his body?

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: It was determined by his fellow literally in -- and he wrote up an official report --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Is he in the crime laboratory?

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: He is in the crime laboratory --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: And he wrote an official report, one copy of which went to the prosecuting attorney --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: In which he stated that it was not a hair from his body?

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Now, when was that report prepared?

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: It is dated December the 7th, 1955.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And how long -- on what dates was the interrogation?

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: On November the 29th and November the 30th.
And the hair --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And prior to the date of that report in any event?

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: Correct, Your Honor and it was -- the hair was delivered to the crime laboratory on the 28th.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, then how do you jump to the conclusion that between the 28th and 30th that it had been discovered it was not a hair from his body and the interrogating officers knew it?
How do you --

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: All we can say on that, Your Honor, is that either they knew it or that they made a statement to the petitioner with this regard whether it was true or false.
Now, we say it doesn't make any difference whether they knew it or whether they -- they told it to him without making the determination.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Well, on this branch of your case, are you making two points -- one that the police used the hair to get the confession and that that was error?

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: Yes, Mr. Justice Fortas.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: And two that there was error before the prosecution to fail to advice the counsel?

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: -- or the petitioner that their expert had reported that the hairs were the same?

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: -- or not the same?

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: Correct.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: So you have those two points?

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: Correct.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: What did counsel do about this when -- on it, wherein from the petitioner that he had told the interrogators it wasn't his hair?

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: The record is silent on that.
Now, of course they --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Does that mean they did nothing?

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: The record doesn't show that they did anything.
But of course they were in a terrible position because what could they do is see that the state never introduced the hair at the trial.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, this -- it would seem to me that if it was a valuable evidence for -- for the defendant now, in this proceeding, it's certainly would have been valuable evidence to him then and if counsel was taking cognizance of what would help him, he would think they would make some kind of an effort to have it determined.
There's a fact --

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: And if --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- whether it was his or not?

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, all they had was what this uneducated cab driver with a two-year high school education at the most told them, he told the investigating authority --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, that's why they have lawyers with more two years education and to take care of his rights in the courtroom that would think.

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: That is correct, and that -- that is the reason that they made the -- the request, to have -- to be permitted to make a scientific examination of the evidence and that was denied.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Did they -- did they state why they wanted to do that?

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Did they say it to him it was because the defendant said that was not his hair and that they wanted to examine that particular item of evidence?

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: No, the motion does not state that.
It does not, no.
Now --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Does it refer that the hair, the vial was distinguished in other physical --
No, it does not.

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: It does not, Mr. Justice Harlan.
Now --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Just one last on that question.
Did these lawyers testify at the least the post-conviction or other proceedings?

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: Yes, they did.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Did they -- did they testify that the motion itself didn't say anything about it?
What it was -- they had in mind when they made the motion?

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: I don't believe they did and I -- I'm not certain about that but I don't think they did.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, in any event, they certainly didn't say they had in mind they wanted an examination of the hair, did they?

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: I don't believe they did.
I am not certain of what of state of the record is on that point.

Now, the -- then the -- then the next step was there was a habeas corpus proceeding in the Northern District of Illinois, relief was denied and that was affirmed by the Supreme -- by the Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit and that was held up by the other counsel.

Then, we came to August of 1963 when a petition for commutation was filed and the -- there was a hearing before the Illinois Pardon and Parole Board and in the course of that hearing there was certain evidence introduced by the prosecution and by the defendants which -- which for the first time cast substantial real doubt on the man's guilt and the -- we were then about two days before the execution, the execution was set for one minute after midnight on August the 23rd and the commutation was denied on August the 20th.
So we proceeded in two channels.
One was, the date for death that have been sent by the Supreme Court of Illinois which was not been in session --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: When -- when does he have counsel for the first time?

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: His parents obtained counsel for him even while he was still being interrogated.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, before he signed the confession?

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: Yes, that's true.
The counsel never saw him until after the confession was signed.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Why -- why not?

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: They -- he was held incommunicado.
He asked to see --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: In other words, (Voice Overlap) refused to let him see him?

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: That is correct and --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But the lawyer tried to see him?

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: I believe the record shows that his lawyer inquiries to get to see him and I believe that the -- the first time that his lawyers saw him was on December the 1st which was the morning following the night when he signed the confession.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Did I ask you before we adjourned if the doctor who made this -- this test of the material in the -- in the vial testified --

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: He did --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- in the case?

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: He did testify, Mr. Chief Justice.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Did -- did he say anything about the hair being attached to --

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: No, he did not.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Was he asked by counsel from cross-examination whether there was any such thing in the vial?

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: He -- there was nothing.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: No mention of it by --

turn.speaker: willard_j_lassers
turn.label: Mr. Willard J. Lassers
turn.text: No mentioned --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- by either side?
